text: I'll ask you a few questions about background, maybe a few general questions about your fiction. All right. And then some specific ones about, you know, specific books and so forth. Fine. Hello, test, test. Well, hello to yourself, Ted. Ah, let's see. Try that, see if that's a little better. Okay. Testing, one, two, yeah, okay, that'll work. As long as his voice, you got the tape rolling? Yeah, make sure you hit the yellow button whenever he talks. All right, you ready? Okay. Okay, tape is rolling. Like I said before, you know, we edit this, so if you say something you want to take back or try to ask a dumb question, just stop me. Okay. Okay, one thing I had a problem with, I wasn't able to find anything. Anything of use to me on your background? Exclusive of writing. Just, you know, what you do, where you, what you, you know, just anything about background. Could you just give me a brief statement on that? Well, let's see. I was a couple of years younger than everybody else. When I got into the football program, it was, it was more or less foreordained that I was going to lose a few teams. You know, you don't have a linebacker two years younger than everybody else without him losing a few parts on the way. It tended to make me rather aggressive. Anyway, I graduated at 16. It took a year at Texas Tech. Then, and almost flunked out, actually. I was typically not ready, I think, for college. I was going in as a chemical engineer. And I changed majors and went to Fort Worth to TCU. Been another year and a half there as a speech student and began to do scripts then. I, at that time, had a fairly good idea that I would be able to write. And I was playing with writing at the time. I went into the Air Force from TCU and spent four years from 51 to early 55 at various places around the country. You know, I didn't get shipped overseas. Then, came to California. Finally got a degree in radio, speech, direction, and writing. For some strange reason, decided not to do anything with that immediately, but went into aerospace engineering. And for the next 15 years, I rose to a not very exciting position, but a senior research engineer. Even though I had a speech degree. And for the time I was, I would say it was about 1967 or 68, I was deciding several things about the aerospace industry. They were, you know, really making up at the expense of the ingenious. Let's say the people that had the ideas were rarely treated all that well. And the managers were the ones who got most of the benefits after all those ideas. So I quit doing design work and simply did it in my own home. Went back for a master's degree at San Jose State while I was still a full-time engineer. And in the meantime, I built and raced a couple of cars, a post-car type. Then, decided to go ahead and get a doctorate at the University of Oregon. Left California. Since then, that's about 12 years ago. And then I got the doctorate. Taught for a few years at a dreadful mid-western university. Came back to the West Coast. And found that I could teach and say whatever it is I need to say. Without anyone, without having to answer to any administrator. So long as I give a bang-up good yarn in the process. So, there's your thumbnail history. Good, okay. By the way, at the end of your answers, I'm probably going to pause a little bit to make sure you're done. It doesn't mean I'm not listening. Understood. Okay, listen. Did you read science fiction as a youngster? I read a little science fiction when I was a kid. I recall my granddad switching off of his old pulp, instant pulp magazine with other railroad engineers and brakemen and so on. And I would occasionally read some of the pulp magazines either. Okay. Then, when I was about, oh, I suppose, 12 years old, I discovered Heinlein and a couple of other science fiction writers that I really did enjoy. And off and on, through my high school years, I would read science fiction, what is now analog, it used to be called astounding. I would read that and not much else. But by the time I was a college freshman and wanted to get into the sciences and engineering, I was what you could call a, you know, a modest fan of science fiction. Okay, you weren't the type then that was a fanatic and put out your own fanzine and went to conventions and so forth. The first, oh, no, I was never really a fan. The first science fiction convention I ever went to, a man named Mark Clifton, who had just won the first Hugo, I believe. He was about the only man I knew who was a writer. And I had already had a couple of stories told to astounding, now analog magazines. And Mark asked me to come along to a world con, which happened to be in Southern California's design. I went, I kind of enjoyed it. But I didn't really make any contact and I didn't go on with it for very long. I simply quit writing science fiction and went back to doing engineering, design, and so forth for years and years. I perceived that there were problems I like to, you know, social and technological problems that I like to address more immediately than I could address them in science fiction. It wasn't until some years later that I realized that I had almost nothing to say about what was done with my abilities. Whatever ingenuity I might have was not going to be used as I chose but as the administrations chose, as long as I worked for some large company. And so I got more and more out of that, did more and more design work, development of all kinds of notions in my home lab. Not just building racing cars but developing the fiberglass rivet technique, developing a multi-manometric gauge gadget that you could put on a prototype automobile. And drive the car at various speeds on a freeway and get wind tunnel data from it. Things like that. I simply wanted to do it and I never had much opportunity to get anything out of it through the industries that I worked in. So I decided to head for those guys. I would do all my work on my own. Okay, listen, in the sources available to me, I don't think I know about those early stories of yours, those early ones for Astounding. What year are you talking about? Let's see. My first published story was early in 1955. I wrote it in 54. It was called Tight Squeeze. And I know it's in several compilations of stories back in the 50s. And about a year and a half later, I guess the summer of 56, I wrote one. I had one published, it is, called Red Rover. Now, Red Rover has been reprinted in an anthology about two years ago. But Tight Squeeze, I believe, has never been reprinted, which is not too surprising as a story. It isn't all that good. As a suggestion of the kind of problems that a mechanic was liable to have in free fall, working in an orbital situation. It was, I think, a pretty good story. So let's say that it was good as a technological flip note, but it was not particularly good as a story. And that was in 55 and 56. I quit writing then for almost 20 years because I had sent another story, which was clearly a fake piece, clearly a complaint about the way we were centralizing in bigger and bigger cities. The story I wrote, which I can't even recall the name of now, it was turned down by Horace Gold at Galaxy. And Horace's scribbled complaint to me was that it was terrific storytelling, but not much of a story. That I was, it was perfectly clear that I was up on a, on a soapbox, haranguing the reader. And Horace was just entertaining, that's all he wanted. Well, that made me mad. I didn't think that my particular position in life was as an entertainer. And I realized if I couldn't make the things that I had to say interesting enough, so that I could entertain and inform at the same time, then I wouldn't write. And that's the truth. I couldn't. I didn't know the craft that well at the time. I could either entertain you or I could write some information down. I could write some information down and hold it. Stop. Just a minute there. I'll think about this and rephrase it. And I could either entertain you and give the reader what he wanted and not do anything I wanted to do. Or I could try to inform the reader and satisfy myself and not give the reader what he wanted. That is not a very good way to do it. Let's face it. The reader is the one who must be satisfied first. He's the person who paid his money for the, uh, for the entertainment. So I need to entertain about 90% first and inform no more than 10%. Okay, good. You anticipated one of my next questions anyhow with that one. That was good. Much of your fiction, at least your later fiction, is set in the late 1980s, 1990s. And I wonder why you're picking that time period so much. I think that the 80s and 90s give me a whole lot more clarity. It's really tough to see what's going on, to have much of a clear vision as to what's going to happen 30 or 40 years from now. I have, um, over the 1950s, I've had some fairly clear notions as to what, uh, the future would hold. And I have a pretty good batting average on that. But just for one example, to look at the, um, oh, my very short and not very, uh, important career in sports car racing, I quit after two or three years and wrote some letters, open letters to editors and so on, of the racing fraternity saying that our overuse of gasoline and this waste of energy was really not in the best interest of the human race and we were all going to be sorry for it. This was in 1961 and 62. And I set about trying to demonstrate how much better machines we could have than we did have. Well, the cars that I built, one of them is out in my garage right now. It looks like next year's bullshit and it's 20 years old. My perceptions of what was going to happen 15, 20, 25 years in the future, um, have been fairly good and I would rather write about things that I feel more firmly, uh, familiar with. It's just awfully hard for me to figure out what's going to happen in the year 2010, let's say. However, I, you know, I am working on it. Okay, all of your stories, it seems to me, novels, novellas, whatever, they're all built around a very strong subject or theme, such things as the media or terrorism or nuclear war and so forth. And I wondered which comes first when you start a book. Does the subject come first and then you look for characters and style and so forth or do the characters come or how do you go about it? I'm in it the first time, Dale. Um, it is the theme usually that comes first. I have on occasion, sometimes just as an exercise or sometimes just for fun or because a friend will have asked, will ask me to do so. You know, like, um, there is an anthology that Larry Niven did based on his book called The Magic Goes Away. And I don't do much fantasy. But Larry's, uh, fantasy was a very clever one, a very good one. It even had a, in a sense, a scientific basis for magic. And, uh, he asked me to do a story for, um, for a sequel. And I was very happy to do that. But it's one of the few stories that I've written that, in which I did not have a, uh, what I consider an important theme to start with. So, as you first, uh, suggested, yes, I'll usually take a theme, then build plot and characters that go along with it. Okay, good. Um, I was surprised what you said about Horace Gold's comment on that story because my impression of your, your writing is that it's extremely fast-paced and exciting. When I pick up one of your books, I can hardly put it down until it's done. And I wondered if that skill is, or that bio, whatever, is something you've acquired or worked at, or does it come naturally to you? I worked my buns off to get it, actually, Harold. You've got to remember that I did get my, uh, my doctorate in communication theory. And media theory is a, um, fairly good-sized flood of that. And studying men like William Stevenson and his play theory of mass communication and so taught me a lot about the kind of entertainment that, um, that an audience is liable to focus on. So, again, as you said, it's something that I had to work at. It didn't just come naturally. In fact, it still doesn't just come naturally. I have to, uh, sometimes go back and say, now, wait a minute, this is, yeah, this is what I was wanting to say, all right, but my God, nobody would be interested. It's dull. Now I've got to go back and figure a way to, uh, to make it interesting. If I can do that 90% or 95% entertainment in a story, I know I can get away with putting in 5% message. Okay, that's a good proportion. It works, I think. Yeah, it does. However, uh, there is a book just about to come out. In fact, it should be out by the time this paper is aired. It's called Pulling Through. And, uh, that is a novel in which, oh, I must have 20% information in there and only 80% entertainment. But it is, again, extremely fat-paced. I've set a, um, a nuclear survival scenario in the context of a great big, um, overbearing and overwhelming bounty hunter in California. The kind of guy who, uh, you know, goes around with weapons all the time and has a fairly high-tech environment. He's a man that, uh, around whom things just happen and they happen fast. But the book is probably 20% information. It's, I guess, the most, uh, thoroughly information-packed novel I've ever written. And, uh, the reviews that are just coming out are very nice reviews. And so far, I haven't heard anybody complain that it's dull. But that is, I think, the biggest risk I take. Yeah, I knew that book was coming out, Pulling Through. I knew it was coming, I just haven't been able to find a copy. Well, I haven't seen one yet either, Daryl. It's probably, uh, maybe two weeks in the future before it'll hit the stand. Yeah, okay, let me focus down on some particular works then. All right. What was the, uh, the impetus behind, uh, Anasazi? Well, for many years, I've been interested in American, North American and Central American, uh, archaeology and anthropology. My master's degree was in American Indian science arts. I had been in the, uh, Anasazi area numerous times and was aware of this mystery that still exists as to why those people moved down to the Anasazi. In fact, I should be more specific. The mystery as to why the American Indians who lived near the cliff dwellings, why they moved down under those cliffs and made those cliff dwellings to begin with. We know why they left, uh, why they abandoned the cliff dwellings because of a great drought that was starving the mouth for 25 years or so. We know about the unbroken, um, tradition of, uh, life in that area for centuries and centuries before they built the cliff dwellings. We still do not know. We do not know today why they built those dwellings themselves. It would seem, well, perhaps they were afraid of something. They were retreating from something. Yet we have no, uh, significant information as to what they were retreating from. Well, it was my idea to set up a scenario that would explain why these people abandoned their homes, their accessible places up on top of the Mesa's, and moved down into a sort of defensive fortification. And, um, since I enjoyed visiting that part of the country, you know, like Villa Pueblo, Acoma, um, Mesa Verde, uh, Isleta, Daniel Defonso, Santa Clara, all the Pueblos in that area. Uh, I enjoyed it a lot, and this gave me a chance to do, uh, to re-familiarize myself with some research, to go back into the area and, um, write a story that tied in so completely with facts. Facts were, um, archaeologists already know. Facts were, um, archaeologists, uh, are, uh, research that a friend of mine had done. He's an anthropologist. Uh, it was not that nobody had done it. It was that it hadn't been published yet. Uh, a friend of mine who was doing his doctoral dissertation on witchcraft rituals in Taos Pueblo. And, uh, I was aware of all this, and I had, uh, access to his tape recordings. And while he was setting about the early stages of his doctoral dissertation, I was already reading those tapes, making notes and so on, so that the book, uh, Anasazi, which came out before his dissertation did, had information that was not in the literature yet. What it amounted to was that I had tomorrow morning's newspaper, and when you have tomorrow morning's newspaper, you always seem smarter than you are. Okay, good. Um, in one way, this work was different from, uh, most of your other later writing, in that it had the, uh, aliens in it, the alien menace theme, and I guess an old stand by a science fiction, the bug-eyed monster thing. Oh, yeah. Uh, was that just a plot device to, uh, to explain the, this Anasazi problem, or was it something you just deliberately chose for some other reason? I'm not sure how to answer that, Daryl. Um, they were the most likely answer I could think of to make it a horror story about a kind of possession, uh, that would possess American Indian kid and turn this thing from a science fiction western detective love story into a science fiction western love horror story. I wanted to try to do just about everything in a very short novel. It was, uh, an exercise in part to see how many kinds of a story I could write without, uh, making it seem jumbled. Well, I had to, it was just a drive in me to see if I couldn't, um, get this scenario of mind, this hypothesis studied by people who's, uh, who work all the time with speech pathology. Yeah, I figured those were actual references. Um. Yes, you're right. Listen, there was one thing you did in that story, which to me was very un-ing-like. And I thought it was time that, uh, someone did some fiction along that line to point out the possibilities for, um, to point out how likely it was that some mental institutions were being, uh, really mishandled, that the patients were being maltreated, um, that nothing very fruitful was going to ever come out of them. And so I wrote the story. Uh, in that story, of course, uh, you write about, uh, I'm not sure of the pronunciation. Is it Maffei, Chris Maffei? Yeah, Maffei. Okay, um, your characters are so real to me that I can't help but think that they're being modeled on real people. And I wonder if that's true. No, actually, Maffei is as much a creature of whole cloth as anybody. Um, there are, of course, partial patches of people that I cram together to make, uh, to make characters. I have noticed, uh, in academia that, uh, while, of course, I value academic, the academic life quite a bit, I would certainly not have tried to take it on about the age of 40 if I didn't, uh, value it a lot. But, uh, the, uh, the single-minded, really lonesome kind of, uh, selfishness that some scholars have, they just, you know, just appalled me. They're not really doing this work because of anybody else. They're doing it because, uh, they want to rise in this, uh, academic priesthood. And Maffei is that kind of name. He is both the best and the worst, uh, of academia put together in the same name. He's gutsy. He's extremely intelligent. He's active. But he's also outrageously selfish. Just as sure as 1984 was science fiction, so was Soft Targets. It, uh, involved some scientific hypotheses about media theory. In 75 or 76, by still mulling the idea over, mulling over the problem, I came across these, uh, these little set of hypotheses about how you could use the model of warfare, you know, the media going to war against the terrorists. And, um, I pretty much had to work that up out of whole cloth. So I had four drawer file cabinets and, uh, oh, perhaps 500 textbooks by the time I was done putting it all together. Yeah, the, uh, the work you put into that, to me, was obvious. Uh, I take it, then, that your, your scenario, your extrapolation is pretty seriously done, and in terms of what you think could happen. Well, yes, so seriously enough that some of my friends, uh, are friends of mine because, as political scientists or, uh, physicists or whatever, they read the book, they read the book and said, oof, an awful lot of, uh, um, of scholarly research has gone into this fund again, and then we would meet somewhere and, uh, get to be a good friend. That doesn't say much about the popularity of a book, although, uh, Systemic Shock has been a bestseller, in science fiction terms, anyway. But it does say a lot about, uh, whether or not the work I did is appreciated by, uh, by experts. And it does seem to be appreciated by experts. That's the, the thing that gets to them the most is that, um, the existing problems of, of, of Islam, of India, of how Japan and, uh, and China are going to work out. The problems that the United States will have, the problems that the Soviets will have 20 years from now, et cetera. That, uh, that it simply grips all those bulls by the horns and wrestles them all at the same time. You know, how likely all this stuff is, who knows? But, uh, at least I did wrestle with all those problems and find a kind of jigsaw puzzle that they would fit into. Yeah, you did it. Well, it was a jigsaw puzzle. You aren't, by any chance, a military strategist or buff in that area, are you? Well... In a small way, yes. Yes. And Reginald Bretner, who is a, one of the better known science fiction writers and, uh, writers about science fiction as well as writers of science fiction. And, uh, Reg has done a, a book on military strategy. There aren't just a whole lot of military strategists around. Certainly not writing books. Reg is one of them. Um, I listen to him a lot. And, uh, of course I follow the stuff in his library from time to time. So, yes, strategy is of some interest to me. Okay, listen, we have to switch the tape here. Can you give me about 10 or 15 minutes more after we switch it? Yeah, I feel like. Yeah. Uh, we just gotta change the tape. We finished it. We finished it. We finished it. We finished it. We finished it.

segments.text: I'll ask you a few questions about background, maybe a few general questions about your fiction.
All right.
And then some specific ones about, you know, specific books and so forth.
Fine.
Okay, David, have we got the tape rolling?
We've got the tape rolling.
Okay, listen, if you can, I am getting a bad feedback if you can find a bad echo.
I can hardly hear my voice.
Let me see.
Hello, test, test.
Well, hello to yourself, Ted.
Ah, let's see.
Try that, see if that's a little better.
Okay.
Testing, one, two, yeah, okay, that'll work.
As long as his voice, you got the tape rolling?
Yeah, make sure you hit the yellow button whenever he talks.
All right, you ready?
Okay.
Okay, tape is rolling.
Like I said before, you know, we edit this, so if you say something you want to take back or try to ask a dumb question, just stop me.
Okay.
Okay, one thing I had a problem with, I wasn't able to find anything.
Anything of use to me on your background?
Exclusive of writing.
Just, you know, what you do, where you, what you, you know, just anything about background.
Could you just give me a brief statement on that?
Well, let's see.
I was a couple of years younger than everybody else.
When I got into the football program, it was, it was more or less foreordained that I was going to lose a few teams.
You know, you don't have a linebacker two years younger than everybody else without him losing a few parts on the way.
It tended to make me rather aggressive.
Anyway, I graduated at 16.
It took a year at Texas Tech.
Then, and almost flunked out, actually.
I was typically not ready, I think, for college.
I was going in as a chemical engineer.
And I changed majors and went to Fort Worth to TCU.
Been another year and a half there as a speech student and began to do scripts then.
I, at that time, had a fairly good idea that I would be able to write.
And I was playing with writing at the time.
I went into the Air Force from TCU and spent four years from 51 to early 55 at various places around the country.
You know, I didn't get shipped overseas.
Then, came to California.
Finally got a degree in radio, speech, direction, and writing.
For some strange reason, decided not to do anything with that immediately, but went into aerospace engineering.
And for the next 15 years, I rose to a not very exciting position, but a senior research engineer.
Even though I had a speech degree.
And for the time I was, I would say it was about 1967 or 68, I was deciding several things about the aerospace industry.
They were, you know, really making up at the expense of the ingenious.
Let's say the people that had the ideas were rarely treated all that well.
And the managers were the ones who got most of the benefits after all those ideas.
So I quit doing design work and simply did it in my own home.
Went back for a master's degree at San Jose State while I was still a full-time engineer.
And in the meantime, I built and raced a couple of cars, a post-car type.
Then, decided to go ahead and get a doctorate at the University of Oregon.
Left California.
Since then, that's about 12 years ago.
And then I got the doctorate.
Taught for a few years at a dreadful mid-western university.
Came back to the West Coast.
And found that I could teach and say whatever it is I need to say.
Without anyone, without having to answer to any administrator.
So long as I give a bang-up good yarn in the process.
So, there's your thumbnail history.
Good, okay.
By the way, at the end of your answers, I'm probably going to pause a little bit to make sure you're done.
It doesn't mean I'm not listening.
Understood.
Okay, listen.
Did you read science fiction as a youngster?
I read a little science fiction when I was a kid.
I recall my granddad switching off of his old pulp, instant pulp magazine with other railroad engineers and brakemen and so on.
And I would occasionally read some of the pulp magazines either.
Okay.
Then, when I was about, oh, I suppose, 12 years old, I discovered Heinlein and a couple of other science fiction writers that I really did enjoy.
And off and on, through my high school years, I would read science fiction, what is now analog, it used to be called astounding.
I would read that and not much else.
But by the time I was a college freshman and wanted to get into the sciences and engineering, I was what you could call a, you know, a modest fan of science fiction.
Okay, you weren't the type then that was a fanatic and put out your own fanzine and went to conventions and so forth.
The first, oh, no, I was never really a fan.
The first science fiction convention I ever went to, a man named Mark Clifton, who had just won the first Hugo, I believe.
He was about the only man I knew who was a writer.
And I had already had a couple of stories told to astounding, now analog magazines.
And Mark asked me to come along to a world con, which happened to be in Southern California's design.
I went, I kind of enjoyed it.
But I didn't really make any contact and I didn't go on with it for very long.
I simply quit writing science fiction and went back to doing engineering, design, and so forth for years and years.
I perceived that there were problems I like to, you know, social and technological problems that I like to address more immediately than I could address them in science fiction.
It wasn't until some years later that I realized that I had almost nothing to say about what was done with my abilities.
Whatever ingenuity I might have was not going to be used as I chose but as the administrations chose, as long as I worked for some large company.
And so I got more and more out of that, did more and more design work, development of all kinds of notions in my home lab.
Not just building racing cars but developing the fiberglass rivet technique, developing a multi-manometric gauge gadget that you could put on a prototype automobile.
And drive the car at various speeds on a freeway and get wind tunnel data from it.
Things like that.
I simply wanted to do it and I never had much opportunity to get anything out of it through the industries that I worked in.
So I decided to head for those guys.
I would do all my work on my own.
Okay, listen, in the sources available to me, I don't think I know about those early stories of yours, those early ones for Astounding.
What year are you talking about?
Let's see.
My first published story was early in 1955.
I wrote it in 54.
It was called Tight Squeeze.
And I know it's in several compilations of stories back in the 50s.
And about a year and a half later, I guess the summer of 56, I wrote one.
I had one published, it is, called Red Rover.
Now, Red Rover has been reprinted in an anthology about two years ago.
But Tight Squeeze, I believe, has never been reprinted, which is not too surprising as a story.
It isn't all that good.
As a suggestion of the kind of problems that a mechanic was liable to have in free fall, working in an orbital situation.
It was, I think, a pretty good story.
So let's say that it was good as a technological flip note, but it was not particularly good as a story.
And that was in 55 and 56.
I quit writing then for almost 20 years because I had sent another story, which was clearly a fake piece,
clearly a complaint about the way we were centralizing in bigger and bigger cities.
The story I wrote, which I can't even recall the name of now,
it was turned down by Horace Gold at Galaxy.
And Horace's scribbled complaint to me was that it was terrific storytelling, but not much of a story.
That I was, it was perfectly clear that I was up on a, on a soapbox, haranguing the reader.
And Horace was just entertaining, that's all he wanted.
Well, that made me mad.
I didn't think that my particular position in life was as an entertainer.
And I realized if I couldn't make the things that I had to say interesting enough,
so that I could entertain and inform at the same time, then I wouldn't write.
And that's the truth.
I couldn't.
I didn't know the craft that well at the time.
I could either entertain you or I could write some information down.
I could write some information down and hold it.
Stop.
Just a minute there.
I'll think about this and rephrase it.
And I could either entertain you and give the reader what he wanted
and not do anything I wanted to do.
Or I could try to inform the reader and satisfy myself and not give the reader what he wanted.
That is not a very good way to do it.
Let's face it.
The reader is the one who must be satisfied first.
He's the person who paid his money for the, uh, for the entertainment.
So I need to entertain about 90% first and inform no more than 10%.
Okay, good.
You anticipated one of my next questions anyhow with that one.
That was good.
Much of your fiction, at least your later fiction, is set in the late 1980s, 1990s.
And I wonder why you're picking that time period so much.
I think that the 80s and 90s give me a whole lot more clarity.
It's really tough to see what's going on, to have much of a clear vision as to what's
going to happen 30 or 40 years from now.
I have, um, over the 1950s, I've had some fairly clear notions as to what, uh, the future would
hold.
And I have a pretty good batting average on that.
But just for one example, to look at the, um, oh, my very short and not very, uh, important
career in sports car racing, I quit after two or three years and wrote some letters, open
letters to editors and so on, of the racing fraternity saying that our overuse of gasoline
and this waste of energy was really not in the best interest of the human race and we
were all going to be sorry for it.
This was in 1961 and 62.
And I set about trying to demonstrate how much better machines we could have than we
did have.
Well, the cars that I built, one of them is out in my garage right now.
It looks like next year's bullshit and it's 20 years old.
My perceptions of what was going to happen 15, 20, 25 years in the future, um, have been
fairly good and I would rather write about things that I feel more firmly, uh, familiar
with.
It's just awfully hard for me to figure out what's going to happen in the year 2010, let's
say.
However, I, you know, I am working on it.
Okay, all of your stories, it seems to me, novels, novellas, whatever, they're all built
around a very strong subject or theme, such things as the media or terrorism or nuclear
war and so forth.
And I wondered which comes first when you start a book.
Does the subject come first and then you look for characters and style and so forth or do
the characters come or how do you go about it?
I'm in it the first time, Dale.
Um, it is the theme usually that comes first.
I have on occasion, sometimes just as an exercise or sometimes just for fun or because a friend
will have asked, will ask me to do so.
You know, like, um, there is an anthology that Larry Niven did based on his book called
The Magic Goes Away.
And I don't do much fantasy.
But Larry's, uh, fantasy was a very clever one, a very good one.
It even had a, in a sense, a scientific basis for magic.
And, uh, he asked me to do a story for, um, for a sequel.
And I was very happy to do that.
But it's one of the few stories that I've written that, in which I did not have a, uh,
what I consider an important theme to start with.
So, as you first, uh, suggested, yes, I'll usually take a theme, then build plot and characters
that go along with it.
Okay, good.
Um, I was surprised what you said about Horace Gold's comment on that story because my impression
of your, your writing is that it's extremely fast-paced and exciting.
When I pick up one of your books, I can hardly put it down until it's done.
And I wondered if that skill is, or that bio, whatever, is something you've acquired or
worked at, or does it come naturally to you?
I worked my buns off to get it, actually, Harold.
You've got to remember that I did get my, uh, my doctorate in communication theory.
And media theory is a, um, fairly good-sized flood of that.
And studying men like William Stevenson and his play theory of mass communication and so
taught me a lot about the kind of entertainment that, um, that an audience is liable to focus on.
So, again, as you said, it's something that I had to work at.
It didn't just come naturally.
In fact, it still doesn't just come naturally.
I have to, uh, sometimes go back and say, now, wait a minute, this is, yeah, this is what I was
wanting to say, all right, but my God, nobody would be interested.
It's dull.
Now I've got to go back and figure a way to, uh, to make it interesting.
If I can do that 90% or 95% entertainment in a story, I know I can get away with putting
in 5% message.
Okay, that's a good proportion.
It works, I think.
Yeah, it does.
However, uh, there is a book just about to come out.
In fact, it should be out by the time this paper is aired.
It's called Pulling Through.
And, uh, that is a novel in which, oh, I must have 20% information in there and only 80% entertainment.
But it is, again, extremely fat-paced.
I've set a, um, a nuclear survival scenario in the context of a great big, um, overbearing
and overwhelming bounty hunter in California.
The kind of guy who, uh, you know, goes around with weapons all the time and has a fairly high-tech
environment.
He's a man that, uh, around whom things just happen and they happen fast.
But the book is probably 20% information.
It's, I guess, the most, uh, thoroughly information-packed novel I've ever written.
And, uh, the reviews that are just coming out are very nice reviews.
And so far, I haven't heard anybody complain that it's dull.
But that is, I think, the biggest risk I take.
Yeah, I knew that book was coming out, Pulling Through.
I'm sorry to say I couldn't find a copy.
That, by any chance, that's not a sequel with, uh, Quantrill in it, is it, from Systemic Shop?
Uh, Pulling Through is a, is a short novel on nuclear survival in the San Francisco Bay Area.
And the short novel is followed in the same book by five articles, non-fiction articles,
detailing some of the gadgetry and techniques that these people use to stay alive.
So that it is not only a fast-paced, short novel, but it is also a manual of nuclear survival.
All of that in a single paperback.
Good, I'll be waiting to get my hands on one of those.
I knew it was coming, I just haven't been able to find a copy.
Well, I haven't seen one yet either, Daryl.
It's probably, uh, maybe two weeks in the future before it'll hit the stand.
Yeah, okay, let me focus down on some particular works then.
All right.
What was the, uh, the impetus behind, uh, Anasazi?
Well, for many years, I've been interested in American, North American and Central American,
uh, archaeology and anthropology.
My master's degree was in American Indian science arts.
I had been in the, uh, Anasazi area numerous times and was aware of this mystery that still exists
as to why those people moved down to the Anasazi.
In fact, I should be more specific.
The mystery as to why the American Indians who lived near the cliff dwellings,
why they moved down under those cliffs and made those cliff dwellings to begin with.
We know why they left, uh, why they abandoned the cliff dwellings because of a great drought
that was starving the mouth for 25 years or so.
We know about the unbroken, um, tradition of, uh, life in that area for centuries and centuries
before they built the cliff dwellings.
We still do not know.
We do not know today why they built those dwellings themselves.
It would seem, well, perhaps they were afraid of something.
They were retreating from something.
Yet we have no, uh, significant information as to what they were retreating from.
Well, it was my idea to set up a scenario that would explain why these people abandoned their homes,
their accessible places up on top of the Mesa's, and moved down into a sort of defensive fortification.
And, um, since I enjoyed visiting that part of the country, you know, like Villa Pueblo,
Acoma, um, Mesa Verde, uh, Isleta, Daniel Defonso, Santa Clara, all the Pueblos in that area.
Uh, I enjoyed it a lot, and this gave me a chance to do, uh, to re-familiarize myself with some research,
to go back into the area and, um, write a story that tied in so completely with facts.
Facts were, um, archaeologists already know.
Facts were, um, archaeologists, uh, are, uh,
research that a friend of mine had done.
He's an anthropologist.
Uh, it was not that nobody had done it.
It was that it hadn't been published yet.
Uh, a friend of mine who was doing his doctoral dissertation on witchcraft rituals in Taos Pueblo.
And, uh, I was aware of all this, and I had, uh, access to his tape recordings.
And while he was setting about the early stages of his doctoral dissertation,
I was already reading those tapes, making notes and so on,
so that the book, uh, Anasazi, which came out before his dissertation did,
had information that was not in the literature yet.
What it amounted to was that I had tomorrow morning's newspaper,
and when you have tomorrow morning's newspaper, you always seem smarter than you are.
Okay, good.
Um, in one way, this work was different from, uh,
most of your other later writing, in that it had the, uh, aliens in it,
the alien menace theme, and I guess an old stand by a science fiction,
the bug-eyed monster thing.
Oh, yeah.
Uh, was that just a plot device to, uh, to explain the,
this Anasazi problem, or was it something you just deliberately chose for some other reason?
I'm not sure how to answer that, Daryl.
Um, they were the most likely answer I could think of to make it a horror story
about a kind of possession, uh, that would possess American Indian kid
and turn this thing from a science fiction western detective love story
into a science fiction western love horror story.
I wanted to try to do just about everything in a very short novel.
It was, uh, an exercise in part to see how many kinds of a story I could write
without, uh, making it seem jumbled.
I couldn't think of anything more, um, logical
than to build upon, very obviously, Hal Clements' story, Needle.
If you remember, Hal Clements wrote the story about a blob-like creature
that lived within a human host.
And, uh, Robert Heinlein's story, The Puppet Master.
Now, uh, let's see.
I'm fairly sure that, uh, Hal Clements did his first.
Right.
And, uh, Heinlein's story was next.
And I decided if I were going to, uh, to leapfrog on the marvelous creatures
they had invented, the least I could do was to take it a bit further.
And if I didn't take it a bit further, um, I was really only, only lifting ideas.
So I used these horrific creatures and, um, took their psychology a bit further
than I thought previous authors had done that.
Right, okay, um, at the end of the, at least at the end of the, uh, edition I have,
you have what you call the post-luti, which indicates maybe some kind of sequel.
Have you planned anything in that area?
No, the post-luti is really just a Latin phrase for after game.
Rather than, uh, talking about work to, uh, to come, talking about, well, talking to the
reader, really, about playing with, with ideas about the characters and settings after the
story is over.
So my post-luti were really simply little devices to ask the reader to, uh, to create his own
story.
Based on what they just finished.
I thought it would be a lot of fun for the reader.
I don't intend to write those stories myself.
Yeah, it was fun.
It got me to thinking.
That's, that's why I mentioned it.
Um, one thing that's always, uh, kept me fascinated in your work is, is the way you extrapolate.
Uh, some of your stories, to me at least, are pretty strictly extrapolated from, from present
technology and ideas.
And you're right, really.
And that's where the, the least, um, the least ingenuity, I would say, is shown.
Um, you know, I show less ingenuity there than I, uh, would show in other areas simply
because I am, as you say, fairly strictly extrapolated.
Yeah, and one, one story in particular, I'm not sure if, if this was extrapolated or not.
That's why I was going to ask about it.
Um, the story that was included with Anasazi in the, in the latest edition of it, the, uh,
portions of this program.
Right.
This idea of precognition or something, are there, is that possible?
Are there studies in this area that you were working with?
I actually developed that idea based on some, uh, term papers that a couple of young women
had sent in to me.
Uh, even though the university where I taught back in the Midwest was pretty repressive on
me, the working with the students was really marvelous.
And, um, I encouraged them to go beyond where we had been going in, in a psycholinguistics
class, for example.
And they did.
And two of those papers skirted the idea of, um, certain chemical therapies that would
help solve certain problems like infant schizophrenia.
And, uh, since the young women's papers did go beyond what I knew, I started checking back
and reading all of their, uh, all their footnotes, citations, and stuff, and found what was, what
sounded to me like a possibility for curing certain kinds of autistic, uh, behavior.
Well, I had to, it was just a drive in me to see if I couldn't, um, get this scenario of
mind, this hypothesis studied by people who's, uh, who work all the time with speech pathology.
Well, I talked to speech pathologists who said, yes, this is a very possible, uh, hypothesis.
It may very well be true.
But, of course, I haven't got time to do it.
And, of course, you're not a pathologist, so you could never get published in any little
quarterly journals anyway.
So, see, I'm afraid we're not going to ever have anything done about this.
And I said, the hell it won't.
I wrote a biofiction story, um, giving chapter and verse in the story about the real, um, research
that had been done back in the 60s.
So that if anyone who deals with, uh, pathological communication happens to notice that those very
real citations, it might spur, um, some new research.
And apparently it did.
Yeah, I figured those were actual references.
Um.
Yes, you're right.
Listen, there was one thing you did in that story, which to me was very un-ing-like.
I hadn't noticed this in any of your other work.
It seems you...
Un-ing-like.
Well, that's a good thing.
You almost have a, well, it seems to be a possibility of time travel with that guy, Fox,
who comes in there.
Ah.
You mean that, that in does not do much in time travel?
Right.
You're right.
I usually don't because it has never, um, seemed to me that it is a very sensible...
It's so paradoxical that I think it might very well be impossible.
You know, a few things may very well be permanently impossible.
And time travel, well, I don't happen to be a believer in time travel, that's all.
I, I have no, uh, uh, I don't think I could say I'm certain it can't happen.
Of course not.
But it's just not one of those things that I consider all that likely.
However, um, I'm certainly not above giving a hint of it once in a while.
But you're right, though.
As a general rule, it is a kind of un-ing-like, uh, uh, piece of a plot.
However, maybe next year or year after that I may decide to, uh, to play with it.
Yeah, there have been some, I thought, some excellent novels written recently on time travel.
Hogan's, uh, Twice Upon a Time, and, uh, what's the, uh, Timescape, I guess, by, um, Benford.
Benford's Timescape.
I was, I was really, uh, fascinated by that.
The alternate worlds make, uh, a lot of sense.
Well, I should say, seem to me to make a kind of theoretical sense.
And I can do it with alternate worlds, um, a little better.
It's hard for me to write a thing which I don't believe.
That's one of the reasons why I don't do fantasy very much.
Okay, what about that, uh, the story, The Devil You Don't Know?
Now, uh, where did your interest in mental institutions come from?
Again, that was a story, a, not a story, really.
It was a paper by a student of mine that discussed the dreadful conditions in some mental institutions.
This was back in the, um, early to mid-70s when this young woman handed me his paper.
And I was really appalled.
And by doing some checking, I found that, uh, she was right in every respect.
And I thought it was time that, uh, someone did some fiction along that line to point out
the possibilities for, um, to point out how likely it was that some mental institutions were being, uh, really mishandled,
that the patients were being maltreated, um, that nothing very fruitful was going to ever come out of them.
And so I wrote the story.
Uh, in that story, of course, uh, you write about, uh, I'm not sure of the pronunciation.
Is it Maffei, Chris Maffei?
Yeah, Maffei.
Okay, um, your characters are so real to me that I can't help but think that they're being modeled on real people.
And I wonder if that's true.
No, actually, Maffei is as much a creature of whole cloth as anybody.
Um, there are, of course, partial patches of people that I cram together to make, uh, to make characters.
I have noticed, uh, in academia that, uh, while, of course, I value academic, the academic life quite a bit,
I would certainly not have tried to take it on about the age of 40 if I didn't, uh, value it a lot.
But, uh, the, uh, the single-minded, really lonesome kind of, uh, selfishness that some scholars have,
they just, you know, just appalled me.
They're not really doing this work because of anybody else.
They're doing it because, uh, they want to rise in this, uh, academic priesthood.
And Maffei is that kind of name.
He is both the best and the worst, uh, of academia put together in the same name.
He's gutsy.
He's extremely intelligent.
He's active.
But he's also outrageously selfish.
And he will sacrifice anybody to any degree for his own private, uh, furthering of himself.
What about Laura?
Is her particular powers, I'm not sure what you'd want to call them, telepathy or empathy or whatever.
Is that, uh, is that something you might believe in or is that just a wild idea?
Well, I think that there is some, um, some hope of that sort of thing being, uh, being legal.
I'm not a, a believer, capital D believer.
But, um, I don't disbelieve either.
I think that that sort of thing might very well be possible.
Okay, let me move on here so I'm sure we'll have time to cover this.
Uh, to move on to your novel, Soft Targets.
Um, would you call that science fiction?
Would I call which science fiction?
Soft Targets.
Yes, I do, because it's, it's sociological science fiction.
Uh, there's engineering science fiction, you know, hard sciences, um, with hardware.
And there are the, let's say, quasi-sciences, like psychology, sociology, and so on.
Just as sure as 1984 was science fiction, so was Soft Targets.
It, uh, involved some scientific hypotheses about media theory.
That was truly the initial, um, the initial impetus for the story, was this theme of what we could do about this uneasy marriage between terrorism and television.
That was a problem I saw in 1971.
And I saw no solution for it that would work in a free society until about 76, I guess.

In 75 or 76, by still mulling the idea over, mulling over the problem, I came across these, uh, these little set of hypotheses about how you could use the model of warfare, you know, the media going to war against the terrorists.
And see what media do when they go to war.
What have they done in the past?
How easy would it be to do it again?
Would it be effective?
And, uh, my conclusions were, yes, it would be.
So then I wrote the novel.
I didn't want to write the novel until I had, uh, a possible solution.
I didn't want to help terrorists do their thing.
But by the time I wrote it, terrorists were already starting to do their thing.
Yeah, I guess the reason I asked, if that was science fiction, it seems to me that you say it's theory, uh, media theory and so forth.
I would have thought that by now that's probably pretty accepted.
Isn't that about your ideas about the media and terrorism?
Not by the media people.
It's not.
They have, uh, the most selfish of reasons not to want that to, uh, be considered true.
And, of course, if they can deny it, then they can continue being irresponsible.
Which is, of course, what they wanted to do all along.
Um, a number of people in the top of our network media, um, I know that they have come across soft targets.
And they are none too pleased with it.
It suggests, um, a level of taking responsibility for one's importance.
You know, if the media is all that important, then isn't it time they took a, um, they recognized their responsibilities to the public in more profound ways.
Well, uh, I say that it is time.
They say that it's not.
Their intent is to make money.
How is that book selling, you know?
Say, how is it selling?
Yeah.
It sold pretty well.
It did not, uh, you know, it didn't go hog wild.
It sold, I would say, it sold well for a first novel.
There were two editions, and I believe Ace Books is going to be bringing out a third edition sometime next year.
Yeah, it seemed to me that that was such a, uh, a book on such a vital contemporary issue.
I thought it might, have you got any movie rights or any interest there?
As it happened, my 27-year-old daughter, who, uh, works at Warner's down south and is an actress, um, she does have a treatment of it.
We have a couple of copies of the book.
And, um, an actor named Joel Hughes is also very high on the idea.
And they're trying to, to, uh, offer that treatment and the book to anyone who would, uh, pay attention to it.
And, um, I think, personally, the chances of it being made into a movie are perhaps one in a hundred.
The one thing, it, uh, it really lays too much blame.
It's very trenchant.
It, uh, when I say too much, I mean for people in the media to be comfortable about it.
It, um, it raises hell with the media leaders.
For one thing, it's not liable to be the kind of, uh, movie that would ever be shown on late-night television.
Because it takes television so much to task.
Why does, why would the TV, uh, people want to beat themselves about their head and shoulders by showing a movie that, uh, snarls about their irresponsibility?
Chances are they wouldn't.
And when people make movies these days, they, uh, are very clearly thinking about the TV rights later on.
Yeah, that book reminded me of another one.
Uh, it's a very different kind of book, but the idea, the power of the media is, uh, Spinrad's Bug Jack Baron.
That's Bug Jack Baron, yes.
Yeah, that was a, uh, that was an interesting one, all right.
Yeah, okay, let me go on for just a few minutes here to Systemic Shock.
Um, was that book hard to write?
Oh, Lord.
You, uh, you've asked a lot of questions that, uh, I have to answer yes to, so you, you must have redone your homework.
Yeah, it took me years to get all the background from it.
Uh, especially with, uh, Asians and, uh, the Indian subcontinent on Asia, all of the variables, the social, geopolitical variables of that, uh, book were enough to drive me crazy.

I talked for historians, and in the case of India, um, more than any other case, I think, whatever I suggested as a scenario for the future, uh, every historian that I would talk to, um, would say, oh, no, uh, every social scientist, no, this can't happen because X, Y, or Z.
Well, if that's not, if that won't happen, then how about this?
No, no, that can't happen.
In short, none of them would ever, um, be willing to speculate on what's going to happen to India.
And, um, I pretty much had to work that up out of whole cloth.
So I had four drawer file cabinets and, uh, oh, perhaps 500 textbooks by the time I was done putting it all together.
Yeah, the, uh, the work you put into that, to me, was obvious.
Uh, I take it, then, that your, your scenario, your extrapolation is pretty seriously done, and in terms of what you think could happen.
Well, yes, so seriously enough that some of my friends, uh, are friends of mine because, as political scientists or, uh, physicists or whatever,
they read the book, they read the book and said, oof, an awful lot of, uh, um, of scholarly research has gone into this fund again,
and then we would meet somewhere and, uh, get to be a good friend.
That doesn't say much about the popularity of a book, although, uh, Systemic Shock has been a bestseller, in science fiction terms, anyway.
But it does say a lot about, uh, whether or not the work I did is appreciated by, uh, by experts.
And it does seem to be appreciated by experts.
That's the, the thing that gets to them the most is that, um, the existing problems of, of, of Islam, of India, of how Japan and, uh, and China are going to work out.
The problems that the United States will have, the problems that the Soviets will have 20 years from now, et cetera.
That, uh, that it simply grips all those bulls by the horns and wrestles them all at the same time.
You know, how likely all this stuff is, who knows?
But, uh, at least I did wrestle with all those problems and find a kind of jigsaw puzzle that they would fit into.
Yeah, you did it.
Well, it was a jigsaw puzzle.
You aren't, by any chance, a military strategist or buff in that area, are you?
Well...
In a small way, yes.
Yes.
And Reginald Bretner, who is a, one of the better known science fiction writers and, uh, writers about science fiction as well as writers of science fiction.
And, uh, Reg has done a, a book on military strategy.
There aren't just a whole lot of military strategists around.
Certainly not writing books.
Reg is one of them.
Um, I listen to him a lot.
And, uh, of course I follow the stuff in his library from time to time.
So, yes, strategy is of some interest to me.
Okay, listen, we have to switch the tape here.
Can you give me about 10 or 15 minutes more after we switch it?
Yeah, I feel like.
Yeah.
